query: Surrealist Memes: Regression or Progression?

summary.claim: Surrealist memes can be seen as a driving force in the progression of meme art

perspectives.text: Surrealist memes approach the absurdity of contemporary life in the same manner as Dadaism, which contended that art doesn’t need to make sense if governments and societies don’t make sense either.

By referencing Dali in the same image as Pepe the Frog, surreal memes accomplish another central goal of Pop Art – to mix high and low culture and elevate ordinary, daily items into the world of fine art.
This ongoing dialogue between various art movements and surreal memes points to the latter’s power as a driving force in the progression of meme art.

summary.claim: Surrealist memes are devoid of any distinct message or point

perspectives.text: Art needn’t have a particular message in order to qualify as art, or even to qualify as good art.
The most deadening influence on art in our time is the belief that content matters more than style.
Surreal memes evade easy understanding or categorization.

summary.claim: Surrealist memes are regressive and lack the ability to sensitize or clarify

perspectives.text: The nihilism of surreal memes reveals their regressive nature.
They traffic in absurdity for absurdity’s sake, which leaves them little hope to evolve into something meaningful or new.
The DNA of Dada was self-destructive [sic]; so too is the DNA of the surreal meme.

summary.claim: Surrealist memes can be a driving force in the progression of meme art

The cost of such technologies is a necessary condition of such progress.

query: Throwback TV: Friends or Seinfeld?

summary.claim: Friends is more influential than Seinfeld

perspectives.text: Friends has set the bar and path for the creation of more successful sitcoms, and without it, there would be no How I Met Your Mother, New Girl or even The Big Bang Theory.
Friends has aged better than Seinfeld, and Netflix paid $100M to stream the series for 12 months, citing that it was the second-most watched program among American viewers in 2018.

summary.claim: Seinfeld is more influential than Friends

perspectives.text: Seinfeld revolutionized television, which is quite impressive for a show “ about nothing.” But it’s precisely because the show’s story lines were about different aspects (and complaints) of everyday life, ranging from the mundane to the controversial, that Seinfeld made such a lasting impact.

Seinfeld pioneered the idea that main characters don’t have to be good or likable, and they can be superficial, peculiar, painfully honest or downright immoral and still make audiences laugh and root for them.

query: (Titanic) Could Jack have been saved?

summary.text: There is enough space on the door for both Jack and Rose to be saved.
The script states that Jack gets off the board and gives his place to Rose so she can survive.
A 2012 episode of MythBusters recreated the famous scene in slightly warmer surroundings and found that the raft could have been made buoyant enough to support their combined weight.
The survival instinct is way stronger than that in everybody, especially in that character, and Jack would have tried more than once.
The door could not have supported the weight of both Jack and Rose, and a recent forensic study confirms this fact.

query: Which is better: Star Wars Vs. Star Trek?

summary.claim: Star Wars is better than Star Trek

perspectives.text: Star Wars is a more visually striking and stimulating franchise that made science fiction cool and approachable.
Star Wars inspired countless movies to follow and spawned ILM, which has forever changed movie special effects.
The spectacular special effects used in Star Wars spawned ILM, created by George Lucas, which has forever changed movie special effects.
Star Wars is a fable-like battle between darkness and light, with a story that is a very effective embodiment of good vs. evil.
The use of medieval symbols, such as knighthood, swords, princesses and wise magicians, gives the Star Wars franchise the sense of a legend.
Star Wars made science fiction cool and approachable, and inspired countless movies to follow.
Star Wars is a more iconic and influential franchise that has inspired many other movies and TV shows.

summary.claim: Star Trek is better than Star Wars

perspectives.text: Star Trek tries to educate its viewers about diplomacy and understanding the other side in a conflict instead of resorting to war.
The Enterprise crew will always prefer reasoning – even at the cost of losing – for the sake of goodwill and of spreading the kindness of the human species across the galaxy.
Star Trek debuted in 1966, just five years after Yuri Gagarin was the first man to journey into outer space and two years before the moon landing.
Star Trek deals with dilemmas that could very well become reality in the coming centuries, when humanity will exhaust Earth’s resources and make its curious and necessary journey to outer space.
Star Trek is a more cerebral and thought-provoking franchise that explores complex themes and ideas.

query: Hamilton – overrated or worth the hype?

summary.claim: Hamilton is worth the hype!

perspectives.text: Hamilton offers valuable and unforgettable lessons about the history of the United States of America, all from the comfort of a theater seat.
Hamilton' s score and lyrics are fresh, innovative and catchy.
The cast, in best Broadway tradition, is well-versed and alternates between the genres without missing a beat… or a breath.
The musical, with its symbolism of resistance and inspiration for artists of color, particularly resonates today and may serve as a comfort or even a springboard towards action to change.

summary.claim: Hamilton is not worth the hype!

perspectives.text: Hamilton has been fortunate to receive unlimited accolades and great reviews, but let’s not forget the less heard voice.
Not everyone wants to pay a fortune to see the musical and those who do are not always impressed with the score, scenery, or have patience to sit through a 2 hour and 45 minute history lesson.
The show, like opera, might be more enjoyable if you know the story and music before seeing it for the first time.

query: Battle of the Bonds: Daniel Craig or Sean Connery?

summary.claim: Sean Connery is the most iconic James Bond due to his portrayal in the 1960s.

perspectives.text: Sean Connery’s mastery of witty dialogue has made his Bond the coolest and most collected of all.
Connery went on to star in six more James Bond movies, cementing how we think of the on-screen character.
He’s come to represent the epitome of 007, and every other Bond since Connery can’t help but be compared to him.

summary.claim: Daniel Craig has humanized the James Bond character, making him more relatable and interesting.

perspectives.text: Craig changed all that. He portrayed a never-before-seen emotional depth that moved Bond away from the slick, pretty-boy stereotype.
Craig’s intensity and vulnerability, combined with his physical toughness gave viewers a darker, more interesting and psychologically complex James Bond than they’d ever seen before.
Craig humanized the Bond character, which no other actor before him did.

query: Should We Cheer for Beauty Pageants or Call for Their Demise?
How great is ‘great literature’ if it needs to be studied to be understood?

summary.claim: Great Literature is a transformative experience that can broaden one's perspective and foster a deeper understanding of oneself and the world.

perspectives.text: Great Literature can be a transformative experience that broadens one's perspective and fosters a deeper understanding of oneself and the world, as it challenges readers to locate its relevance and impact on society, both positive and negative.
By deconstructing literature, we can place ourselves in the same stories that have always made humans tick, and identify a sense of purpose; we can challenge ourselves and our beliefs.

Literature is solitary and meant for intimate consumption, not class reading, and it is through this personal experience that we create the meaning we need and extract our experience from the rich layers of a truly great text.
The study of Great Literature divides us into two camps: those who get it, and those who don’t, and it can alienate readers if the only way to understand it is through a course load.

summary.claim: Great Literature is often inaccessible to readers due to its complex language and dynamic concepts, leading to alienation and a loss of interest in literature.

perspectives.text: The study of Great Literature divides us into two camps: those who get it, and those who don’t, and it can alienate readers if the only way to understand it is through a course load.
If readers can’t grasp it after hours of study, then they might think literature isn’t for them, and they may lose touch with books and drift, instead, to more accessible and less challenging texts.
Great Literature can’t be gulped down, it needs to be digested slowly, and the lessons discovered by taking time to truly understand Great Literature are, perhaps, the richer ones.

query: Back to the Future: Musical or Movie. Which is better?

summary.claim: The movie is better than the musical in Back to the Future

perspectives.text: The story belongs to the movie. After all, that’s where most of us first experienced it. Even if viewers get to see both versions with fresh eyes, the movie story is simply richer. It has more action scenes that aren’t in the stage version. There are easter eggs that cleverly appear throughout the movie (like the images on Doc’s walls when the movie begins) which are missing in the musical, and there is no Einstein in the musical. The story was originally written for film and not for the stage, with an expansive canvas in mind, and this is where it works better.

While the musical version is a fun, electrifying show, a feast for all senses that captivates its audience with (26) songs and spectacle, the movie is driven, instead, by the story and character development.
The movie is richer in terms of action scenes and Easter eggs, and it was originally written for film, which is where it works better.

summary.claim: The musical is better than the movie in Back to the Future

perspectives.text: Unlike the movie, which has a nostalgic tone, the musical looks ahead to the future. It takes a more cynical look at the past. For instance, in the live show, the song introducing the 1950s speaks about women smoking cigarettes that doctors prescribed and people using asbestos as a way to keep the home cozy and warm.
The musical takes a more cynical look at the past, which is a refreshing change from the nostalgic tone of the movie.
The stage production keeps the theme of 1900, but many of the show’s songs actually came out after the 2001 movie, which adds to the viewer’s visceral experience.

query: Does Nicki Minaj Empower or Objectify women?

summary.claim: Nicki Minaj Empowers women

perspectives.text: Nicki Minaj’s performances exemplify female empowerment. She uses her sexuality to make money, and she clearly enjoys her own sexuality. Making it acceptable for women to shed their inhibitions and enjoy men’s bodies is a positive message.
Minaj appropriates an aggressively sexual male track, “ baby got back,” and tells her female audience to care more about themselves than about society’s demands and beauty ideals.
Making it acceptable for women to shed their inhibitions and enjoy men’s bodies is a positive message.

summary.claim: Nicki Minaj Objectifies women

perspectives.text: The way Nicki Minaj unashamedly displays her body, in general and in her performances, gives off an overly sexualized view of women.
Whether intentional or not, Minaj enforces sexist stereotypes suggesting that a woman’s value is directly proportional to how she looks and how men judge and assess her attractiveness.
Minaj encourages onlookers to objectify her and women in general.

perspectives.text: Moulin Rouge offers countless breathtaking moments that are etched into the spectator's mind.
The show has a story that’s big on emotions, a tragic play with big drama, big love, and big jealousy.
This show has a story that’s big on emotions, and the love at the center of the story is a sacred entity.
Moulin Rouge is, at heart, a tragic play.

summary.claim: Mr. Saturday Night is the hottest ticket on Broadway

perspectives.text: Mr. Saturday Night that feels like a fully rounded play with songs more so than just a musical.
There is something about Mr. Saturday Night that feels like a fully rounded play with songs more so than just a musical.
This is because much of the show’s key moments happen through dialogue and not through song.

All humans need privacy. Privacy allows us to mitigate our social environment and our internal world

If we were to talk about documentaries and whether they are right or wrong, what we commonly cite as morally wrong is the unjustified interruption. It is for that reason that people making documentaries have to remain as unnoticed as possible.

Artists generating ideas and using their effort to produce an intangible good have a property right over those ideas and the products that arise from them.

query: The Perspective on Comic-Con: Is It Worth Attending?

summary.claim: Comic-Con is a safe haven for self-expression and creativity.

perspectives.text: Comic-Con provides a platform for people to express themselves in a variety of ways, unjudged and unapologetically.
Comic-Con's art of cosplay has inspired a growing, acceptable and profitable affirmation of self-expression.
Comic-Con's creativity and individuality has even been used to protest workplace dress codes.

summary.claim: Comic-Con has become too mainstream and watered down, losing its original purpose.

perspectives.text: Comic-Con is getting increasingly mainstream and watered down, which disappoints die-hard comic book fans.
More Hollywood and TV stars are coming to promote their big movies and shows, attracting crowds addicted to celebrity rather than comic books.
The event is now more of a media blitz for movie studios and television producers to market their latest superhero movies and fantasy shows.

query: Is slam an accepted form of poetry?

summary.claim: Slam poetry is a step back into more traditional kinds of formal poetry

perspectives.text: A distinctive quality of Slam poetry is its clever use of rhyme and wordplay, With this in mind, one could argue that Slam is actually a step back into more traditional kinds of formal poetry, as opposed to the rhyme-less free verse that is commonly used today.
Poet and critic Dana Gioia cites the “denial of a musical texture” as one of the main problems with contemporary poetry; Slam, by contrast, embraces musical texture, and arguably even enhances it.

summary.claim: Slam poetry is not an accepted form of poetry

perspectives.text: While undeniably some sort of art form, Slam seems to be closer to other modes of artistic expression than to poetry.
People attend poetry slams like they would a show at the theater, and the audience who shows up doesn’t need to have any understanding of poetry to enjoy themselves.

summary.claim: Slam poetry is an enhancement of what written poetry already does

perspectives.text: Slam poems supply the same outlet to unleash your inner convictions and random musings as does written poetry.

The human voice captures emotion as well as the written word; rather than assessing the nature of Slam as “other” than poetry, it makes more sense when viewed as an enhancement of what written poetry already does, i.e., each are art forms that provide a way to effectively communicate emotions.

summary.claim: Slam poetry is not suitable for classroom teaching

perspectives.text: There are people who dedicate their lives to studying poetry and still have trouble understanding its meaning.

The greatest poets write about adult experiences, e.g, love, work, history, politics, solitude etc. As a result great poetry requires an adult mind to grasp its full meaning and teaching it in schools means that students develop a disliking for poetry before they are even fully capable of appreciating it.

query: Does Fox News add balance or propaganda to the media landscape?

summary.claim: Fox News adds balance to the media landscape by providing a conservative viewpoint.

perspectives.text: Conservatives have long disagreed with the mainstream media's liberal tilt, but before the launch of Fox News, they were at least forced to engage with the news seen by a major share of Americans. With many right-leaning viewers now getting their information from Fox News, they are not exposed to the viewpoints many Americans take for granted.
Having a conservative voice among the news channels to question assumed wisdom and counter perceived bias makes sense in theory.

summary.claim: Fox News adds propaganda to the media landscape by promoting baseless conspiracy theories and partisanship.

perspectives.text: Fox News has never won a Peabody Award, and more than 60% of statements made on Fox News by pundits or their guests were rated Mostly False, False, or Pants on Fire by Politifact.

Winning over conservative viewers has sometimes led the network to promote baseless conspiracy theories, and the reflexive partisanship has manifested itself in a constant criticism of Obama and seemingly uncritical defense of former President Trump.

query: Is a Hotdog a Sandwich?

summary.claim: Is a hotdog a sandwich?

positive.text: According to the Merriam-Webster dictionary, a sandwich is defined as two or more slices of bread or a split roll having a filling in between.
Oscar-Mayer’s head of marketing, Gregory Guidotti, declared it so, and even the late Supreme Court Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg ruled that a hotdog is a sandwich.
Jon Chonko, the founder of Scanwiches, features in its catalogue a multitude of bread-wrapped links, from the humble frankfurter with onion and ketchup to the bold Italian sausage with peppers.

negative.text: A hotdog is not a sandwich.
A recent poll found that nearly 60% of Americans do not believe that hotdogs are sandwiches.
Joey Chestnut, a former 9-time winner of the national Nathan’s Hotdog Eating Contest, tweeted his belief that hotdogs are not sandwiches.
Americans spent more than $8.3B on hot dogs and sausages in US supermarkets in 2023, so it seems that they know what they’re talking about: sandwiches are groovy, but the hotdog is sacrosanct.

query: Do Standardized Tests Improve Education?

summary.claim: Standardized tests improve education by teaching important skills and promoting accountability among schools.

perspectives.text: Standardized tests didn’t appear out of nowhere; there is evidence that they teach students important skills.
Standardized tests ensure the education level in America is up to par – for everyone.
Prominent testing critic Diane Ravitch, Research Professor of Education at New York University, concedes standardized testing has value...

The US’s Every Student Succeeds Act, which began in 2016, requires states to use proficiency on standardized exams as a method of holding elementary, middle and high schools accountable for their students’ success.
This was intended to close the gap between minority and poverty-stricken students with those from higher-income families.

summary.claim: Standardized tests do not improve education and may even hinder it by being expensive and biased towards wealthy students.

perspectives.text: Standardized tests are astronomically expensive, using taxpayer dollars that could be put towards better use.
A Rutgers University study shows as having a positive impact on student achievement.
There are schools all over America that are in dire need of updated materials, funding for teachers, school psychologists, more after-school programming, etc.
If they can afford to go to an expensive school or prep course, and if they have more time to study because they don’t have to work, then they will most likely perform better on such tests.

query: The Perspective on Time – Is It Linear or Cyclical?

summary.claim: Time is cyclical

perspectives.text: Our most common time measurement systems are cyclical.

The repetition of 60 seconds into a minute, 60 minutes into an hour, 24 hours into a day, seven days into a week, (roughly) four weeks into a month, (roughly) three months into a season, and four seasons into a year.
This cyclical nature of time supports the notion that time is cyclical.

summary.claim: Time is linear

perspectives.text: Time is linear because of the different and cumulative ways we can record and measure it.
The use of linear, metric counting measures supports the notion that time is linear.

query: Milk: Is It Healthy or Harmful to Drink?

summary.text: Soy milk can serve as a healthy alternative to cow's milk as it doesn't contain lactose and contains 7 grams of protein in one cup, which is much higher than other milk alternatives.
Soy milk can also be fortified with calcium and vitamin D, which are essential for bone health.
Soy milk contains carbs called fructooligosaccharides, which nourish our bodies' supportive intestinal bacteria, important for digestion.

The Perspective on the Public Apology

summary.claim: A public apology can facilitate rehabilitation and provide closure for victims of sexual harassment or assault.

perspectives.text: A public apology opens the way for wide-scale rehabilitation. It seems that we, as a society, are finally evolving from an environment that has long pushed sexual harassment under the rug to one that acknowledges that to create a brighter future, we must acknowledge our past.
A public apology is the aggressor acknowledging guilt, which provides some sense of closure for the victim.

A public apology is the aggressor acknowledging guilt, which provides some sense of closure for the victim. Where there is trauma, closure can be the difference between lifelong scars and some form of peace.

summary.claim: A public apology can be insincere and turn into an appeal for sympathy, rather than a genuine acknowledgment of wrongdoing.

perspectives.text: In some cases, the public apology has come across as more like a non-apology. After being accused of sexual harassment by three different women, two of whom were former aides, New York Governor Andrew Cuomo was criticized for his apology because it focused more on his alleged actions having been misinterpreted instead of the alleged actions themselves.
Negative attention is part and parcel of being a public figure. There is a protocol to a public apology that has the monotonous feel of writing lines on a chalkboard.
Disingenuous apologies that read as excuses are merely excuses.

query: The Perspective on Political Correctness

summary.claim: Political correctness is not doing anything for minorities

perspectives.text: Political correctness is a form of social cultural superiority, alienating and belittling those who do not conform to the norms.
The political process is far more responsive to the claims of the privileged, and the privileged are far better organized and engaged in the political process.

summary.claim: Political correctness is not doing anything for minorities

perspectives.text: The ability to prosecute politicians incentivizes political opponents to search out past actions by said politicians so as to immobilize them politically.

summary.claim: Political correctness is not doing anything for minorities

perspectives.text: Research has demonstrated a connection between economic inequality and political voice, with the privileged being far better organized and engaged in the political process.

query: Is America Still Great?

summary.claim: America is still great

perspectives.text: America is still a great country with a strong economy and a rich cultural heritage.
Despite the challenges it faces, America remains a beacon of freedom and democracy in the world.

summary.claim: America is not great

perspectives.text: America's infrastructure is crumbling and its healthcare system is in disarray.
The country's history of abuse and mistreatment of its citizens, particularly women, is a stain on its reputation.

query: Can People Change Their Minds?

summary.claim: People can change their minds

perspectives.text: Positivity can go a long way in changing people’s minds. According to the Washington Post, a review of Reddit’s ChangeMyMind forum revealed that people who remained polite and practiced hedging– a linguistic tool used to make an argument appear less threatening (\u201it may be that\) – succeeded more often in changing people’s minds.

People who had practiced positive self-affirmation before entering an argument were more influenced by the argument than those who had only argued, without the benefit of the self-affirmation activity.

Many people who have eaten meat their whole lives have become vegetarians. People change religions or take one up after a lifetime of atheism. They change political parties, too; people tend to become more conservative with age.
There is no thought system in existence, no matter how deeply entrenched, that cannot ultimately be undone.

summary.claim: People cannot change their minds

perspectives.text: The notion that people do not change their minds contradicts what we readily observe about the human experience.
Fines are imposed with the purpose of dissuading and disincentivising the action for which they are being fined for.
We should not carelessly wash our laundry in public, we should be more careful with our personal information.

query: Should We Ban Unpaid Internships?

summary.claim: Maintaining a system of unpaid internships can ensure that businesses don't take advantage of interns or keep people trapped in unpaid jobs without any outside knowledge.

perspectives.text: As Prohibition demonstrated, if you ban something that people really want, they’ll still find a way to get it. If unpaid internships were banned, businesses would still get unpaid workers (especially in coveted or over-populated industries), in a way which may be unregulated and unsupervised.

By maintaining a system of unpaid internships that is transparent, we can make sure that businesses don’t take advantage of interns or keep people trapped in unpaid jobs without any outside knowledge.

summary.claim: Unpaid interns tend to feel that their work is unimportant because they aren’t being paid for it, consequently leading some to expend only a meager effort.

perspectives.text: Unpaid interns tend to feel that their work is unimportant because they aren’t being paid for it, consequently leading some to expend only a meager effort.
This doesn’t establish long-term loyalty. Businesses, then have to train someone with no loyalty to the company who could leave at any time.

summary.claim: Paid interns feel more engaged with the company and more enthusiastic to give their all to the job.

perspectives.text: Paid interns feel more engaged with the company and more enthusiastic to give their all to the job.
Meanwhile, paid interns feel more engaged with the company and more enthusiastic to give their all to the job.

summary.claim: Unpaid internships are no different than any of these examples. When young people work in unpaid internships, they are essentially building their CVs.

perspectives.text: Unpaid internships are no different than any of these examples. When young people work in unpaid internships, they are essentially building their CVs.
By attaching their names to a reputable firm, that firm’s reputation stands out on the interns’ CVs.

summary.claim: College students who had internships are 15% less likely to be unemployed in the years after graduating college than those who didn’t.

perspectives.text: College students who had internships are 15% less likely to be unemployed in the years after graduating college than those who didn’t.
In fact, college students who had internships are 15% less likely to be unemployed in the years after graduating college than those who didn’t.

summary.claim: Colleges offer career services, internships, job shadowing, job fairs, and volunteer opportunities in addition to a wide variety of courses that may provide a career direction.

perspectives.text: Colleges offer career services, internships, job shadowing, job fairs, and volunteer opportunities in addition to a wide variety of courses that may provide a career direction.
Over 80% of college students complete internships before graduation, giving them valuable employment experience before entering the job market.

query: The US coronavirus response: Have we done enough or not?

summary.claim: The US coronavirus response has been effective in protecting public health.

perspectives.text: The US has implemented various measures to slow the spread of the virus, including social distancing and mask mandates.
The US government has also invested heavily in vaccine development and distribution.

summary.claim: The US coronavirus response has been insufficient in protecting public health.

perspectives.text: The US response has been criticized for being slow to adapt to the evolving pandemic, and for not doing enough to support vulnerable populations.
The US has struggled to balance individual freedoms with public health measures, leading to controversy and resistance to certain restrictions.

query: ADHD Diagnosis:  Too Much or Just Right?

summary.claim: Too much or just right? The number of ADHD diagnoses has increased significantly, but the actual prevalence of the disorder may be lower than the current diagnosis rate.

perspectives.text: The number of ADHD diagnoses has increased significantly, but the actual prevalence of the disorder may be lower than the current diagnosis rate.
The increased diagnosis rate may be due to environmental factors, such as diet, sleep deprivation, and stress, which can masquerade as ADHD symptoms.
The expanded diagnostic criteria in the DSM may lead to more frequent diagnoses, but this does not necessarily mean that the prevalence of ADHD is increasing.

summary.claim: The increased ADHD diagnosis rate may be a result of stigma and misinformation, which can lead to unnecessary diagnoses and treatment.

perspectives.text: The stigma of mental illness, including ADHD, can lead to self-stigmatization and discourage individuals from seeking treatment.
The media's inaccurate reporting of ADHD data can contribute to the public's perception of diagnosis rates, leading to unnecessary diagnoses.

query: Is the Body Positive Movement as Positive as it suggests?

summary.text: The Body Positive Movement promotes positive body image and self-acceptance, which can lead to improved mental health and well-being.
The Body Positive Movement can be seen as promoting unrealistic beauty standards, which can lead to body dissatisfaction and negative self-image.

Is Honesty the Best Policy?

summary.claim: Honesty is the best policy because it builds trust and prevents health risks.

perspectives.text: Society is built on trust, and dishonesty poses health risks to society.
Honesty protects integrity and prevents the spread of misinformation.

summary.claim: Honesty is not always the best policy because it can be self-serving and hurt relationships.

perspectives.text: Our motivation for truth-telling is often more self-serving than pure.
Honesty can wound people closest to us and harm relationships.

query: Climate Change – Act now, or question the urgency of the threat?

summary.claim: Act now

perspectives.text: Climate change is a pressing global issue that requires immediate attention and action.
Fines for causing climate change can serve as a deterrent and encourage individuals and organizations to take action.
The consequences of climate change will be severe and far-reaching, making it imperative to act now.

summary.claim: Question the urgency of the threat

perspectives.text: The effects of climate change may be overstated, and it is essential to consider alternative explanations and perspectives.
The cost of addressing climate change may outweigh the benefits, and it is crucial to prioritize other pressing global issues.
The media and government hype surrounding climate change may be contributing to unnecessary alarm and inaction.

query: Open vs. Closed Space Work Environments

summary.claim: Open office spaces can improve employees' emotional wellbeing by reducing work-related stressors, such as the need to appear in constant productivity.

perspectives.text: Closed office spaces provide workers with increased physical health safety and improve employees' emotional wellbeing, as they are less exposed to work-related stressors.
Closed office spaces improve employees' emotional wellbeing, as they are less exposed to work-related stressors, including anxiety, cardiac issues, and digestive problems.

summary.claim: Open office spaces can inhibit productivity, reduce face-to-face interactions, and increase employee interruption.

perspectives.text: Open work environments negatively affect collaboration, actually reducing face-to-face interactions by 70%, and can lead to increased employee interruption, reduced levels of concentration, and lower levels of motivation.
Open office spaces without any barriers can inhibit productivity, as researchers at Harvard have found that open work environments negatively affect collaboration.

query: Comfortably Numb: The Perspective on epidurals

summary.claim: Epidurals are a safe and effective way to manage pain during childbirth

perspectives.text: Epidurals are high-tech, low-dose, and focused on helping moms achieve maximum control and participation in their deliveries.
Epidurals pose no adverse effects to fetal health, and severe side effects for mothers are uncommon.
Epidurals can help to control blood pressure and heart rate, and ultimately safeguards mothers against serious complications that can arise during delivery.
In cases where mothers are affected by complex heart disease or a bad airway, having an epidural early on in labor can help to control blood pressure and heart rate.
Epidurals are just as effective today as they were in the past.
Pain management is not only about easing pain but providing emotional comfort.

summary.claim: Epidurals may have serious side effects, including nerve damage and death

perspectives.text: The side effects that can accompany any kind of general anesthetic treatment, including epidurals, range from itchy skin and day-long headaches to temporary or even permanent nerve damage.
Five percent of women report their epidurals had no effect on their pain.
Temporary or even permanent nerve damage can occur with epidurals.
In exceedingly rare cases, even death can occur with epidurals.
The least welcome side effect of an epidural is when it takes no effect at all.

query: Breast vs. Bottle: which is better for babies?

summary.claim: Bottle it, baby
Breast is best

query: The Perspective on Prom – Antiquated or Timeless?

summary.claim: Prom is a positive experience for teenagers that helps them build confidence and self-expression.

perspectives.text: Prom provides students a model for seizing and appreciating life’s moments – a practice that, if internalized, will certainly make for happier adults.
The celebration provides a real stage for peer pressure – including the pressure of outdoing each other regarding asking a potential date to prom (dubbed, “ promposal pressure ”).

summary.claim: Prom is an outdated and exclusive event that only serves to highlight social pressures and financial burdens.

perspectives.text: Prom began in the late 1800s in the event halls of the nation’s elite universities like Harvard and Yale, when university education of any kind (let alone Ivy League education) was a privilege reserved for the ultra-wealthy.
The price tag of attending remains Ivy League – the average parent may find himself or herself spending between an estimated $600-$2,000 on prom per child.
Dress codes mostly target female students, equating female dress with sexuality and ultimately discouraging young ladies’ right to choose their attire.

query: Are Vaccines Safe or Risky for Your Kids?

summary.claim: Vaccines are safe for your kids.

perspectives.text: Major health organizations, such as the World Health Organization, CDC, and FDA, all say that vaccines are safe, relying on decades of studies to back up their claims.

Medical experts, who have studied health for most of their professional lives, are overwhelmingly pro-vaccines as well, with some supporting them so strongly that they go as far as dismissing families from their practice if the parents refuse to vaccinate their kids.

summary.claim: Vaccines may pose a risk to your kids.

perspectives.text: It has been argued that giving vaccines to children can potentially prevent the immune system from doing its job, making kids more susceptible to getting sick in the long term.

Kids are born with immune systems, which naturally help the body fight off diseases. Yet, it has been argued that giving vaccines to children can potentially prevent the immune system from doing its job, making kids more susceptible to getting sick in the long term.

query: The Perspective on Ayahuasca: Is it worth trying?

summary.claim: Taking ayahuasca can lead to transformative experiences and help treat depression, with preliminary studies showing reduction of depressive symptoms over the course of two weeks after taking the drug.

perspectives.text: Ayahuasca can supposedly lead to a transformative experience by bringing unconscious thoughts to light, helping people face and overcome their fears, or loss, as was the case with Prince Harry, providing perspective, and improving overall mood.
One of the perils of many drugs is their addictive quality – which ayahuasca doesn’t have; taking it won’t induce tolerance of the drug.
More research needs to be done, but initial findings support ayahuasca as a healer, especially for people trying to process grief or overcome trauma.

summary.claim: Taking ayahuasca can cause psychotic episodes, particularly in people with a history of mental illness, and may not be worth the risk of putting your psychological welfare to the test.

perspectives.text: Taking ayahuasca can cause psychotic episodes, particularly in people with a history of mental illness, such as paranoia, suicidal ideation, and psychotic delusions for weeks at a time.
Taking ayahuasca can cause violently ill, purging throughout their psychedelic trip, which may be because of potentially harmful ingredients in ayahuasca.
Taking ayahuasca can cause psychotic episodes, particularly in people with a history of mental illness, and may not be worth the risk of putting your psychological welfare to the test.

query: The Perspective on Physician-Assisted Suicide

summary.claim: Physician-assisted suicide should be legal because it allows individuals to choose the time and manner of their death.

perspectives.text: The degree to which physical pain and psychological distress can be tolerated is different in all humans. Quality of life judgements are private and personal, thus only the sufferer can make relevant decisions.
A PAS system puts the expertise of the doctor and the experience of the patient at the forefront of the issue and views both perspectives rightly as the most credible in a given situation.
Death has proven to be a sensible option taken by sensible people in cases of chronic pain or diseases that steadily remove our sense of self.

summary.claim: Physician-assisted suicide should not be legal because it can lead to the exploitation of vulnerable individuals and the loss of trust in the medical profession.

perspectives.text: The guiding principle of medical ethics is to do no harm: a physician must not be involved in deliberately harming their patient.
Legalising assisted suicide also places an unreasonable burden on doctors.
Ending the life of a patient goes against all they stand for.

query: Should homework be assigned in elementary school?

summary.claim: Should homework be assigned in elementary school?

perspectives.text: Having some homework is good, but having a lot of homework isn't the greatest.
Having some homework is good, but having a lot of homework isn't the greatest.

summary.claim: Should homework be assigned in elementary school?

perspectives.text: Homework can take the enjoyment out of learning and is often stressful, boring, and tiring.

query: Are Government Soda Taxes Fair?

summary.claim: Soda taxes can help Americans make educated decisions about their health and food choices.

perspectives.text: Research shows that warning labels can reduce soda consumption.
A John Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health study suggests that labels can reduce soda consumption.

summary.claim: Soda taxes infringe on Americans’ rights to a free market.

perspectives.text: Capitalism works on the basic principle of supply and demand, which is a consumer-driven system.
A soda tax most likely won’t deter consumers from buying soda.
